Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of a youth wearing a festival wreath, probably Harpocrates. Heavy eye-lids and long curly hair. Fronds or feathers in background. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of a white coating or light slip. Red-brown Nile silt fabric, with abundant mica and sand inclusions. Head only.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis with local parallels (Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA669). Unprovenanced late Ptolemaic parallel has a similar headdress (Török 1995, no.89, however see also early Roman parallel no. 95). Török, L. 1995, Hellenistic and Roman Terracottas from Egypt, Roma.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.066) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4599 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
